title: Edward H. Forney
text:
Edward Hanna Forney (August 16, 1909 – January 21, 1965) was a highly decorated officer of the <a href="United%20States%20Marine%20Corps">United States Marine Corps</a> with the rank of <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a>. He is most noted for his part during the <a href="Hungnam%20evacuation">Hungnam evacuation</a> during the <a href="Korean%20War">Korean War</a>, the largest U.S. amphibious evacuation of civilians, under combat conditions, in American history.
Early years.
Forney was born on August 16, 1909, in <a href="Denver%2C%20Colorado">Denver, Colorado</a>, as the son of engineer Edward Francis Hanna Forney and his wife Pauline Lancaster Peyton. His family moved many times due to father's job and young Edward spent childhood in <a href="Havana">Havana</a>, <a href="Cuba">Cuba</a>, <a href="Hollywood">Hollywood</a>, <a href="California">California</a>, <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> and finally in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> He also attended <a href="St.%20John%27s%20College%20High%20School">St. John's College High School</a> there in 1927 and was admitted to the <a href="United%20States%20Naval%20Academy">United States Naval Academy</a> at <a href="Annapolis%2C%20Maryland">Annapolis, Maryland</a>. During his time at the academy, Forney was active in the <a href="American%20football">football</a>, <a href="cross%20country%20running">cross country running</a> or <a href="water%20polo">water polo</a> and graduated on June 4, 1931, with <a href="bachelor%27s%20degree">bachelor's degree</a>. He was commissioned a second lieutenant in the Marine Corps on the same date.
Many of his classmates had distinguished careers and became <a href="general%20officer">general officer</a>s: <a href="John%20S.%20McCain%20Jr.">John S. McCain Jr.</a>, <a href="Horacio%20Rivero%20Jr.">Horacio Rivero Jr.</a>, <a href="Charles%20T.%20Booth">Charles T. Booth</a>, <a href="Lawson%20P.%20Ramage">Lawson P. Ramage</a>, <a href="Bernard%20F.%20Roeder">Bernard F. Roeder</a>, <a href="Frederick%20L.%20Wieseman">Frederick L. Wieseman</a>, <a href="Frederick%20J.%20Becton">Frederick J. Becton</a>, <a href="Charles%20B.%20Brooks%20Jr.">Charles B. Brooks Jr.</a>, <a href="Ernest%20B.%20Ellsworth">Ernest B. Ellsworth</a>, <a href="Wilmer%20E.%20Gallaher">Wilmer E. Gallaher</a>, <a href="Andrew%20J.%20Hill%20Jr.">Andrew J. Hill Jr.</a>, <a href="Harlan%20T.%20Johnson">Harlan T. Johnson</a>, <a href="Frederic%20S.%20Keeler">Frederic S. Keeler</a>, <a href="Edward%20J.%20O%27Neill">Edward J. O'Neill</a>, <a href="Forsyth%20Massey">Forsyth Massey</a>, <a href="Berton%20A.%20Robbins%20Jr.">Berton A. Robbins Jr.</a>, <a href="Kinlock%20C.%20Walpole">Kinlock C. Walpole</a>, <a href="Nelson%20K.%20Brown">Nelson K. Brown</a>, <a href="Austin%20R.%20Brunelli">Austin R. Brunelli</a>, <a href="Edward%20J.%20Dillon">Edward J. Dillon</a>, <a href="Robert%20E.%20Fojt">Robert E. Fojt</a>, <a href="Bankson%20T.%20Holcomb%20Jr.">Bankson T. Holcomb Jr.</a>, <a href="Lewis%20C.%20Hudson">Lewis C. Hudson</a>, <a href="Clifford%20H.%20Shuey">Clifford H. Shuey</a> or <a href="Samuel%20G.%20Taxis">Samuel G. Taxis</a>.
Upon his graduation, Forney was ordered to <a href="the%20Basic%20School">the Basic School</a> at <a href="Philadelphia%20Navy%20Yard">Philadelphia Navy Yard</a> for further officer training and graduated one year later. He then served with 1st Marine Brigade in <a href="Haiti">Haiti</a> for brief period, before he was attached to the Marine detachment aboard the battleship <a href="USS%20Arkansas%20%28BB-33%29">USS "Arkansas"</a>. Forney spent 30 months with that vessel and took part in the cruise to <a href="Plymouth">Plymouth</a>, <a href="England">England</a>, <a href="Nice%2C%20France">Nice, France</a>, <a href="Naples">Naples</a>, <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, and <a href="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a>.
He then served a brief stint at <a href="Marine%20Corps%20Recruit%20Depot%20Parris%20Island">Marine Barracks, Parris Island</a>, <a href="South%20Carolina">South Carolina</a>, and <a href="Quantico%2C%20Virginia">Quantico, Virginia</a> and subsequently completed the regular course at <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Field%20Artillery%20School">Army Field Artillery School</a> at <a href="Fort%20Sill">Fort Sill</a>, <a href="Oklahoma">Oklahoma</a> in June 1939. Forney was then ordered to the <a href="Marine%20Corps%20Base%20San%20Diego">Marine Corps Base San Diego</a> and attached to the <a href="2nd%20Battalion%2C%2010th%20Marines">2nd Battalion</a>, <a href="10th%20Marine%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">10th Marine Artillery Regiment</a> and served under Lieutenant Colonel <a href="John%20B.%20Wilson">John B. Wilson</a> as commander of Battery E.
Forney was then transferred to the newly activated <a href="1st%20Light%20Antiaircraft%20Missile%20Battalion">1st Defense Battalion</a> under Lieutenant Colonel <a href="Bertram%20A.%20Bone">Bertram A. Bone</a>. This new type of marine units consisted of the batteries with <a href="5%26quot%3B/51%20caliber%20gun">5"/51 caliber gun</a>s, <a href="searchlight">searchlight</a> and aircraft <a href="sound%20locator">sound locator</a> and antiaircraft groups with <a href="M2%20Browning">M2 Browning</a> and <a href="M1917%20Browning%20machine%20gun">M1917 Browning machine gun</a>s and was ideal for the defense of the U.S. naval bases in South Pacific from the attack from the sea and air.
World War II.
Forney was transferred to the staff of Amphibious Corps, Pacific Fleet under Major General <a href="Clayton%20B.%20Vogel">Clayton B. Vogel</a> in October 1941 and sailed as major for Pacific theater one year later. He was stationed in <a href="Noumea">Noumea</a>, <a href="New%20Caledonia">New Caledonia</a> and following the redesignation to <a href="I%20Marine%20Amphibious%20Corps">I Marine Amphibious Corps</a> he was attached as <a href="liaison%20officer">liaison officer</a> and observer to <a href="Marine%20defense%20battalions">9th Defense Battalion</a> under the command of Lieutenant Colonel <a href="William%20J.%20Scheyer">William J. Scheyer</a> in summer 1943.
He took part in the capture and subsequent occupation of <a href="Rendova%20Island">Rendova Island</a> during <a href="New%20Georgia%20Campaign">New Georgia Campaign</a> at the beginning of July 1943 and received the <a href="Bronze%20Star%20Medal">Bronze Star Medal</a> with <a href="%26quot%3BV%26quot%3B%20Device">Combat "V"</a> and <a href="Navy%20Unit%20Commendation">Navy Unit Commendation</a> for his service there. Forney, who just distinguished himself in last campaign, was ordered to <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a> in order to relieve his Naval Academy classmate, lieutenant colonel <a href="Samuel%20G.%20Taxis">Samuel G. Taxis</a> as commanding officer of <a href="3rd%20Defense%20Battalion">3rd Defense Battalion</a> on August 26, 1943. He was promoted to the rank of lieutenant colonel for his new assignment.
Following a brief stay there, 3rd Defense Battalion was ordered to <a href="Guadalcanal">Guadalcanal</a> in September 1943 and then took part in <a href="Bougainville%20Campaign">Bougainville Campaign</a> in November of that year. He landed on <a href="Bougainville%20Island">Bougainville</a> right behind the first waves of assault troop and commanded his battalion during the occupation and defense of <a href="Cape%20Torokina">Cape Torokina</a>. His unit provided support to ground troops ashore until December 1943 and Forney received <a href="Commendation%20Medal">Navy Commendation Medal</a> with <a href="%26quot%3BV%26quot%3B%20Device">Combat "V"</a> for his service at Cape Torokina, Bougainville.
Forney then took part in consolidation of <a href="North%20Solomon%20Islands">Northern Solomons</a> and following the redesignation of his unit to <a href="3d%20Light%20Antiaircraft%20Missile%20Battalion">3d Antiaircraft Artillery Battalion</a> in June 1944, he led his unit back to Guadalcanal. One of Forney's last assignment on <a href="Guadalcanal">Guadalcanal</a> was construction of camp near the village of Tetere and he was subsequently transferred to <a href="10th%20Marine%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">10th Marine Regiment</a>, <a href="2nd%20Marine%20Division%20%28United%20States%29">2nd Marine Division</a>. He served as Regimental executive officer under his old superior, Colonel <a href="Bertram%20A.%20Bone">Bertram A. Bone</a> and participated in the amphibious exercise on <a href="Saipan">Saipan</a> in order to prepare 10th Marines for upcoming <a href="Okinawa%20campaign">Okinawa campaign</a>. However 10th Marines served as floating reserve force, and Forney did not see combat.
Later service and Korean War.
Upon the <a href="surrender%20of%20Japan">surrender of Japan</a>, Forney took part in the occupation duties near <a href="Nagasaki">Nagasaki</a> and finally returned to the United States in February 1946. He was subsequently promoted to the rank of colonel on May 1, 1948, and ordered to <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, where assumed duties as advisor to the <a href="Inter-American%20Defense%20Board">Inter-American Defense Board</a>. Forney served in this capacity until December 1948, when he was ordered for instruction at <a href="Armed%20Forces%20Staff%20College">Armed Forces Staff College</a> in <a href="Norfolk%2C%20Virginia">Norfolk, Virginia</a>.
Forney graduated in July 1949 and joined <a href="Naval%20Amphibious%20Base%20Coronado">Troop Training Unit, Amphibious Training Command, Pacific Fleet</a> at <a href="Coronado%2C%20California">Coronado, California</a>, under the command of Brigadier General <a href="William%20S.%20Fellers">William S. Fellers</a>. He served as Chief of Mobile Training Team Able and took part in the amphibious training of <a href="United%20States%20Pacific%20Fleet">U.S. Pacific Fleet</a> units. He was ordered to <a href="Japan">Japan</a> in April 1950 in order to train army division for upcoming <a href="Operation%20Blue%20Hearts">Operation Blue Hearts</a>, landing at <a href="Pohang">Pohang</a>.
He was subsequently given additional temporary duty as assistant chief of staff for plans with <a href="1st%20Cavalry%20Division%20%28United%20States%29">1st Cavalry Division</a> under Major General <a href="Hobart%20R.%20Gay">Hobart R. Gay</a>. Forney was later decorated with the <a href="Legion%20of%20Merit">Legion of Merit</a> by the army for his service within amphibious training of army divisions in Japan and later with 1st Cavalry Division.
Colonel Forney was subsequently appointed deputy chief of staff, <a href="X%20Corps%20%28United%20States%29">X Corps</a> under Lieutenant General <a href="Edward%20M.%20Almond">Edward M. Almond</a> and his principal duties were to advise Almond on the use of Marine and navy forces. He took part in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Inchon">Inchon Landing</a> and <a href="Second%20Battle%20of%20Seoul">recapture of Seoul</a> in September 1950 and received <a href="Air%20Medal">Air Medal</a> while engaged in observation flights over enemy held territory.
On November 27, 1950, Chinese launched massive offensive and sent 9th Army to infiltrate the northeastern part of <a href="North%20Korea">North Korea</a>. They surprised the <a href="X%20Corps%20%28United%20States%29">X Corps</a> units at the Chosin Reservoir area and quickly encircled 30,000 United Nations troops. The Chinese enriclement was later broken and U.N. forces retreated to the port city of <a href="Hungnam">Hungnam</a> for evacuation. Colonel Forney was appointed Hungnam evacuation officer by General Almond and organized the withdrawal of over 100,000 servicemen – and their equipment, supplies, and vehicles – and evacuated over 100,000 North Korean refugees, <a href="Hungnam%20evacuation">the largest U.S. amphibious evacuation</a> of civilians, under combat conditions, in American history.
Forney was decorated with second <a href="Legion%20of%20Merit">Legion of Merit</a> for the organization of Hungnam evacuation and subsequently took part in the <a href="blockade%20of%20Wonsan">blockade of Wonsan</a>. He was ordered to the United States at the beginning of June 1951 and assumed temporary command of <a href="Naval%20Amphibious%20Base%20Coronado">Troop Training Unit, Amphibious Training Command, Pacific Fleet</a> at <a href="Coronado%2C%20California">Coronado, California</a>. He held that command until he was relieved by Brigadier General <a href="John%20T.%20Selden">John T. Selden</a> one month later.
He was ordered to <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, <a href="France">France</a> in September 1951 and spent next two years as an instructor at <a href="NATO%20Defense%20College">NATO Defense College</a>. Forney then served assignments with the U.S. Element, Standing Group, NATO, Office of the Secretary of Defense (OSD), as a Member of the International Planning Teams and on U.S. Joint and Combined Committee.
In August 1956, Forney was attached to the <a href="Office%20of%20the%20Secretary%20of%20Defense">Office of the Secretary of Defense</a> in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, and served with assistant secretary for international security affairs as assistant for special programs until June 1957. Forney was subsequently ordered back to <a href="Korea">Korea</a> and appointed commanding officer, U.S. Marine Corps Component, U.S. Naval Advisory Group. In this capacity he served as U.S. Marine Corps advisor to the <a href="Republic%20of%20Korea%20Marine%20Corps">Republic of Korea Marine Corps</a>. During this time, Forney helped establish the 1st Marine Division base in Pohang, for which the division named a road in his honor in 2010. Forney retired from the Marine Corps after 28 years of active service in June 1959 and was advanced to the rank of <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a> for having been specially commended in combat. He also received <a href="Commendation%20Medal">Army Commendation Medal</a> for his second tour of duty in Korea.
Vietnam War.
Following his retirement from the Marines, Forney assumed assignment as the Public Safety Advisor with the U.S. Operations Mission (USOM), <a href="Agency%20for%20International%20Development">Agency for International Development</a> at the <a href="U.S.%20Embassy%20in%20Saigon">U.S. Embassy in Saigon</a>, <a href="South%20Vietnam">South Vietnam</a>. While in this capacity, he had an opportunity to analyse the situation in the country and relationship between Vietnamese civilians and U.S. military. As an veteran of <a href="United%20States%20occupation%20of%20Haiti">Haitian campaign</a>, he used his own experiences and proposed that the United States operation in South Vietnam should not be tied in with the <a href="MAAG">MAAG</a>; but rather an effort to be linked with the Civil Guard, the Self-Defense Corps, and the local Militia in the village and boondock level. This would be similar to the Guardia effort in <a href="Nicaragua">Nicaragua</a> or the Gendarmerie operation in <a href="Haiti">Haiti</a> and <a href="Santo%20Domingo">Santo Domingo</a>.
Forney met with then-Chief of Staff, <a href="Headquarters%20Marine%20Corps">Headquarters Marine Corps</a>, Lieutenant general <a href="Wallace%20M.%20Greene">Wallace M. Greene</a> in Saigon in February 1963 and discuss his conclusions with him. Unfortunately Forney's health began failing and he was diagnosed with the cancer. He lost his fight with the illness on January 21, 1965, and died in <a href="Letterman%20Army%20Hospital">Letterman Army Hospital</a> in <a href="San%20Francisco">San Francisco</a>, <a href="California">California</a>. He was buried with full military honors at <a href="Arlington%20National%20Cemetery">Arlington National Cemetery</a>, <a href="Virginia">Virginia</a>.
